Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Medium: Collaborative Research: TribalNet: Expanding Internet Accessibility and Participation on Native American Reservations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Tribal communities represent the final frontiers of Internet access in the U.S., with fast (broadband) Internet access available to fewer than 10% of Native Americans on tribal reservation lands. The lack of broadband access is caused by a collection of challenges, including remote terrain, inadequate funding, and complex telecommunication policies. Yet Native Americans need reliable avenues for participation and contribution to Internet content to strengthen their communities. This project investigates technologies that will increase Internet availability on reservation lands. Further, it will develop new methodologies of disseminating Internet content to reservation residents, prioritizing content by relevance during periods of limited connectivity. Ethnographic methods and interviews of Native Americans residing on the reservations will be incorporated to ensure usability and utility of the proposed solutions. Through the trial of the solutions within Southern California tribal communities, the work has the potential to reach over 2,700 homes and 60 community anchor institutions. Within the three participating institutions, the PIs will include in courses results from the research that demonstrate the positive humanitarian impact of computer science in order to increase the appeal of computer science to female and minority groups.

The goal of the research is to make critical inroads to addressing the lack of Internet access on tribal reservations, to increase the number of Native American reservation residents who are able to engage with, create, and disseminate Internet and on-line social network content. This project will achieve this goal through four related elements: (1) develop an architecture suitable for a multi-network setting comprised of cellular, wireless ISP and whitespace networks, where coverage, cost and network speed varies; (2) develop a tribal content distribution network, consisting of computation and storage at cellular, wireless ISP and white space towers across the reservation, that delivers content to and receives content from end users; (3) conduct a limited empirical study of Internet use and organizational network technology use capacity within the TDV community using ethnographic methods to inform the content prioritization and distribution mechanisms. Interviews will also be conducted and engaged in prototyping activities as needed to ensure that the system interfaces support use and administration by members of the community; (4) collect and analyze multiple years worth of traffic from the TDV network to develop models of content relevance and consumption to prioritize content distribution in the network.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Despite the broad uptake of advances in cyberinfrastructure and broadband networks across the U.S., Native Americans remain the least connected. The lack of connectivity has negative implications for economic activity, education, and health care, among others. Beyond connectivity, Native Americans are one of several segments of American society systematically underrepresented in computing. The lack of representation results from and contributes to only limited engagement with indigenous knowledge or ?ways of knowing? reflected in computing technologies and user interfaces. 

Through three project phases, our research enhances tribal connectivity and builds connections between connectivity and greater participation in computing industries. First, our early stage research identified organizational and policy strategies that can reduce barriers to tribal broadband uptake. In particular, we identify tribal internet service providers? (ISPs) role as ?technological mediators? in broadband adoption and ways equipment providers and policy makers can better support their efforts. Although the original model of technological mediation defined three obstacles mediators encounter during the process of network technology adoption (technical, commercial, and structural), how these obstacles unfold during mediation was not clearly defined. Through an ethnographic case study with a small, rural, tribal ISP, we identified the complex interplay between the dynamic technological environment of the so-called ?TV white spaces? technology and the experiences of the mediator. While it is widely recognized that commercial markets for new technologies take time to mature, our research highlights the costs incurred by rural adopters who need to localize technologies designed for more urban locales. 

In the second phase, we position the needs of tribal communities within the broader rural and marginalized populations, in which they are frequently embedded. Generally, ensuring all people benefit from Internet access requires addressing the complex needs of systematically marginalized communities. Whether in the US, Europe, or developing nations, minimizing this digital divide has taken on greater urgency as local governments and social service agencies aim to provide services online, such as education and healthcare. In some cases, temporary subsidies make connectivity affordable. For instance, during the Covid-19 pandemic, school systems and network operators provided subsidized or no-cost temporary connections for children to participate in online schooling. We argue such temporary solutions are problematic as the systems to which the marginalized connect view connectivity as a stable construct ? a family is either connected or not. Drawing on our work with Southern California Tribal Chairman?s Association (SCTCA), together with examples of marginalized communities from around the globe, we propose technical, organizational, and policy solutions that can help overcome issues of temporary connectivity for Native Americans and others. While Native Americans face unique challenges that deserve specialized approaches, for some elements such as connectivity, aligning with the larger community of marginalized persons can foster development of economies of scale and thereby reduced costs.  

In the third phase, we turned our attention to the challenges of Native Americans? participation in computing more broadly. This effort ties our previous focus on network connectivity to the issues of decolonizing IT training for Native Americans and other indigenous peoples. In this work we expand postcolonial computing theory beyond participatory design into the domain of decolonizing IT training curricula. We tie the lessons learned about technological mediation and the network equipment industry to IT education through a frame of the ?knowledge enterprise.? In this last phase, we emphasize the exercise of power within the systems of technological education, innovation and diffusion. The framing highlights the challenges indigenous people face within the system, and suggests decolonizing education as a means to challenge the status quo and potentially broaden participation in computing. Pragmatically, this work builds a bridge between the work funded through the TribalNet project and a spin-off project (a dissertation study) of a Canadian STEM education program working with First Nations.  

Over all, the intellectual merits of this project include: (1) extension of the model of technological mediation, shedding light on the dynamic and emotional elements of network equipment adoption, (2) bridging models of technological mediation and postcolonial computing through the construct of the knowledge enterprise, and (3) identifying decolonized IT education as a means to broadening participation in design leading to technologies, networking and otherwise, more appropriate for Native American contexts. The broader impacts include recommendations for policymaking and organizations in the design, adoption and funding of programs to enhance Native American network connectivity and use.
